message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, history of symptoms in other family members, and the X-ray and enema suggests cystic fibrosis. Enzyme-replacement therapy is the most appropriate long-term treatment for cystic fibrosis, as it helps with the malabsorption of nutrients and fatty acids. Rectal suction biopsy and surgical correction are used for Hirschsprung's disease, which is not suggested by the symptoms and imaging. Duodenal atresia and cholecalciferol are not relevant to the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and imaging suggest a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis, which can cause malabsorption and pancreatic insufficiency leading to bulky stools with flatulence. Enzyme-replacement therapy can help replace the enzymes that the patient is missing and improve digestion. Rectal suction biopsy and surgical correction is used to treat Hirschsprung's disease, which is not suggested by the symptoms, and duodenal atresia repair is used to treat an obstruction in the upper part of the small intestine, which is also not suggested by the symptoms. Cholecalciferol is a form of Vitamin D and is not the appropriate treatment for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and medical history suggest cystic fibrosis, which affects the digestive system and causes bulky stools with flatulence. Enzyme-replacement therapy is the most appropriate long-term treatment for this condition. Rectal suction biopsy and surgical correction are used for Hirschsprung disease, while duodenal atresia repair is used for newborns with duodenal atresia. Cholecalciferol is a form of vitamin D and is not indicated for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn girl's symptoms are consistent with meconium ileus, which is associated with cystic fibrosis. Fecal elastase is a good diagnostic test for pancreatic exocrine insufficiency in patients with cystic fibrosis. Therefore, enzyme-replacement therapy is the most appropriate long-term treatment for this patient's condition. Rectal suction biopsy and surgical correction are used for Hirschsprung's disease. Duodenal atresia repair is used for congenital duodenal obstruction. Cholecalciferol is a form of vitamin D and is not the appropriate treatment for this patient.

Rectal suction biopsy and surgical correction are used for Hirschsprung disease, duodenal atresia repair is used for the blockage in the upper part of the small intestine, and cholecalciferol is a form of vitamin D and is not appropriate for this condition.

The patient’s symptoms and imaging findings suggest cystic fibrosis, which is confirmed by the decreased fecal elastase and negative D-xylose test. Enzyme-replacement therapy is the most appropriate long-term treatment for pancreatic insufficiency in CF. Rectal suction biopsy and surgical correction is indicated for Hirschsprung disease, which is not suggested in this case. Duodenal atresia repair is indicated if there is perinatal obstruction, which is not the case in this patient. Cholecalciferol is a type of vitamin D supplementation and would not be the appropriate treatment for this patient’s condition.

Rectal suction biopsy and surgical correction are used to treat Hirschsprung’s disease, duodenal atresia repair is used to treat duodenal atresia, and cholecalciferol is used to treat vitamin D deficiency.

Rectal suction biopsy and surgical correction is a treatment for Hirschsprung's disease, which presents with different symptoms. Duodenal atresia is typically diagnosed in neonates and requires surgical intervention. Cholecalciferol is a form of Vitamin D and is not the appropriate treatment for this condition.

Enzyme-replacement therapy can help alleviate the symptoms and decrease the risk of further complications. Duodenal atresia repair is for an obstruction in the duodenum, but there is no indication of such obstruction. Cholecalciferol is a vitamin D supplement and does not address the patient’s underlying condition.
